citeinfo.title: Pre- and post-settlement fire regimes in mountain big sagebrush steppe and aspen: the northwestern Great Basin

pubinfo.publish: Eastern Oregon Agricultural Research Center, Oregon State University

descript.abstract: Fire is an important disturbance in sagebrush steppe ecosystems, influencing plant dynamics, composition, and structure. The balance between woody and herbaceous species in sagebrush steppe communities strongly depends on the amount of time between fires. This time interval has increased considerably since Eurasian settlement in the late 1800s. As a result, pinyon-juniper woodlands and the density and cover of shrubs in the more mesic sagebrush steppe communities of the northwestern Great Basin have significantly increased. Many private landowners and public land managers are interested in restoring fire as a way to improve range health, livestock grazing conditions, and wildlife habitat. Unfortunately, most fire-management and restoration programs are based on little or no historical information about pre-settlement fire regimes. This report describes the pre- and post-settlement fire regimes for the mountain big sagebrush steppe and aspen-dominated ecosystems in the northwestern portion of the Great Basin. The results indicate that fires burned approximately every 10-20 years pre-settlement. This compares to present conditions, where many sites have not burned in the last 100 years and only a few burned 50 years ago. The authors suggest that information on pre-settlement fire regimes and the impacts of altered fire regimes on ecosystem structure and composition is important in developing and supporting effective prescribe fire programs.
